This study presents a new system and control design for an active tool holder that can effectively suppress vibration and chatter in internal turning. The controller accounts for the influence of tool deflection during a preceding cut affecting the dynamics of the current cut, a key source of instability in machining processes. To deal with variability in dynamic behavior due to changing of the tool mounting conditions and overhang length, a robust H-infinity controller is synthesized based on a linear-parameter-varying (LPV) description of the machining dynamics. The parametric dependence allows the robustness levels and modal properties of the control system to be easily tuned in a workshop setting to achieve the best possible vibration reduction performance. The controller design accounts for the time-delayed feedback from cutting forces, and also the need to avoid spillover instability of unmodeled high frequency modes. The method is applied using a tool holder that integrates piezoelectric bending actuators and strain sensors in such a way that the overall size and shape of the tool is unaltered, thereby providing the functionality and ease of operation necessary for widespread adoption in manufacturing industries. Experiments conducted on a lathe machine demonstrate that root-mean-square vibration levels can be reduced by over 95% (and peak-to-peak values reduced by approximately 90%) in unstable cutting regimes, allowing high material removal rates with good surface finish. For stable cutting, the system can also reduce vibration by 10% to 50%, depending on cutting conditions

By synthesizing diverse data-driven methodologies, it offers organizations a road map to industry 4.0 concepts, enhancing efficiency, effectiveness, and overall excellence. The identified collection of methodologies provides a nuanced approach to addressing challenges in each stage of the Six Sigma process, filling a vital gap in the current literature.

Express Directions and prohibitions: Countries generally follow the comply-or-explain approach. Mandatory corporate governance provision are found in very few countries, India being one of these. The Companies Act, The SEBI Act and its regulations, The IBC and a host of other related acts and regulations impose mandatory provisions on companies and their employees/directors about the actions they must take, the manner of taking such actions and what they must avoid. For example, there are eligibility criteria and disqualification provisions for the directors. The director has to act in good faith and perform duties with reasonable care, skill and diligence and avoid any conflict of interest. There are specific provisions regarding manner, standards and timelines for publishing financial statements, calling the meetings of the board and its committees and calling the AGM. Any violation can attract penal action against the management as well as against the director. Non-executive and independent directors have fiduciary duties and are liable for acts or omissions of the company which occurred with their knowledge, attributable through board process, with their consent or connivance or where they have not acted diligently. The IBC has provisions to hold directors personally liable when there are incipient signs of weakness in the company and the directors have not acted in the best interests of the creditors. Besides civil and criminal liabilities directors may even be asked to compensate from their personal wealth when they knew or ought to have known and didn't exercise enough caution to protect creditors' interest

Corporate governance frameworks worldwide typically adhere to a comply-or-explain approach, allowing flexibility in implementation. However, India stands among the few jurisdictions where corporate governance mandates are legally binding. Enforced through the Companies Act, SEBI Act, Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC), and associated regulations, these provisions impose explicit obligations on companies, directors, and employeesdictating required actions, procedural compliance, and prohibitions. Directors must meet strict eligibility criteria, operate in good faith, exercise reasonable care, skill, and diligence, and proactively avoid conflicts of interest. Regulatory mandates also govern financial disclosures, board and committee meetings, and Annual General Meeting (AGM) timelines, with non-compliance attracting stringent penal consequences. Non-executive and independent directors bear fiduciary responsibilities and can be held accountable for company misconduct if it occurs with their knowledge, through board processes, or due to negligence. The IBC further extends liability to directors when early financial distress signals emerge, ensuring they act in creditors' best interests. Beyond civil and criminal penalties, directors may face personal financial liability if they fail to exercise due caution in safeguarding stakeholders' interests.

The constitution of committees of the board are similarly prescribed. The role of Audit Committee, AC has been critically defined. The AC must have at least two-third independent directors. All RPTs must be pre-approved by the AC. Rules for material RPTs have been made even more stringent. The materiality thresholds have been tightened. Material RPTs require approval from majority of minority shareholders-where related parties cannot vote. The Nomination and Remuneration Committee, NRC is another important committee consisting of non-executive directors and headed by an independent director. Separate committees have been prescribed for risk management and for stakeholders interests.

The manner of appointment of directors also needs a relook. The Companies Act and the SEBI LODR envisage the creation of a Nomination and Remuneration Committee, NRC. But, for want of a prescribed norm regarding the manner of selection of independent directors, it is not unlikely that the NRC is still being guided by the promoter or the CEO, depending upon the type of the company. A wider consultation involving minority shareholders and a bigger pool to choose from is needed. Minority shareholders have no role in the selection process, except for voting for or against a resolution. The Companies Act has a provision for appointing a director representing the small shareholders. But that provision has been kept in abeyance so far. In the UK, for example, shareholders can propose directors for nomination or remove serving directors. The USA has ample examples during recent years of management nominees for appointment as directors getting defeated and proposals for appointment from smaller shareholders being approved. Similarly, management proposals on compensation are getting rejected. A beginning can be made by providing for members owning above a certain threshold, say 1% of the company, being enabled to propose names to the NRC. These names can be examined along with other names before the NRC. Reasons for accepting or not recommending a name can be mentioned when the final resolution is put to vote.

The process of appointing directors requires a comprehensive reassessment to enhance transparency and shareholder participation. While the Companies Act and SEBI LODR mandate the establishment of a Nomination and Remuneration Committee (NRC), the absence of clear guidelines on selecting independent directors leaves room for promoter or CEO influence, depending on the companys structure. A more inclusive approach, involving minority shareholders and expanding the candidate pool, is essential. Currently, minority shareholders have no role beyond voting on resolutions, and the provision for appointing a director representing small shareholders remains unimplemented. In contrast, countries like the UK allow shareholders to propose or remove directors, while in the US, shareholder-driven nominations and rejections of management-backed candidates have gained traction. To align with global best practices, India could introduce a mechanism enabling shareholders with a minimum stakesay 1%to propose candidates for the NRCs consideration. These nominations should be evaluated alongside other candidates, with the NRC providing transparent justifications for its selections or omissions when presenting the final resolution for shareholder approval.

Experiments to measure oxygen opacity at stellar interior conditions have been performed at the National Ignition Facility in a Discovery Science campaign. These experiments utilize the Opacity-on-NIF platform with a sample comprised of O, Mg, and Si. The spectral data from the Opacity Spectrometer cover the 10002000 eV photon energy range showing bound-free continuum absorption from O and line absorption from Mg and Si. DANTE and the Gated X-ray Detector are employed to measure the sample plasmas temperature and density, respectively. Initial data show lower transmission than expected by theoretical models, raising questions of whether potential background or data uniformity concerns could produce systematic errors in the inferred transmission. Here, we investigate three concerns thought to be important for the oxygen opacity data, including instrumental scattered background, sample self-emission non-uniformity, and backlight continuum non-uniformity. Additionally, we show the effect of a recently developed method to account for 2nd order crystal reflection. The total effect of these concerns on one experiment is found to be small compared to the observed difference between the inferred transmission and a model calculation at the inferred temperature and density. Thus, we conclude that these potential sources of systematic error cannot account for the observed difference, increasing the likelihood of a real effect due to the high temperature and density conditions. However, because this is only a single experiment, we cannot make a firm conclusion. More experiments measuring the opacity and necessary calibrations are needed to assess the reproducibility and uncertainty of this result.

The remodeling phase, the last step of wound healing, can last anywhere from a few months to many years and aims to improve the tissue's structural integrity, strength, and flexibility. Fibroblasts are crucial at this point because they help collagen fibers cross-link and reorganize, significantly increasing the wound site's tensile strength. Collagen production first peaks then levels out, and excess collagen is broken down selectively by matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) to create a balanced matrix structure. Growth factors that help in ECM remodeling, such as fibroblast growth factor 1 (FGF1) and fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF2), are essential for strengthening scar tissue and preventing excessive fibrosis. In the best-case scenario, this remodeling process leaves little scarring; however, problems like insufficient matrix remodeling or prolonged inflammation can cause fibrosis or hypertrophic scarring. These understandings of cellular and molecular mechanisms are essential for creating therapeutic strategies that maximize healing, particularly in chronic wounds where ongoing inflammation prevents proper healing, underscoring the necessity of focused interventions to promote efficient remodeling and regeneration

In this article we reformulate an orbital based average atom model in terms of the single-particleGreen's function. This means that integrals over energy along the real axis can instead be deformed into the complex energy plane, along any (numerically convenient) contour. The advantage to this is that the Green's function lying along the real axis is broadened at complex energies by a Lorentzian of half-width equal to the imaginary part of the complex energy. Therefore any structures that need to be resolved for accurate real energy integrations, including narrow resonances, are broadened automatically in the complex plane. The contour integration over energy can therefore be easily evaluated without adaptive grids for resonance tracking.

However, the effects of industrial activities brought back to their initial location are not just positive. The phenomenon hides potentially negative consequences that need to be highlighted in order to be anticipated and tackled with mitigating policies. The aim of this paper is to measure the social consequences of back-shoring at the local level. By measuring the effect that back-shoring has on wages of high- vs low-skilled workers in the manufacturing sector at NUTS2 level, a double dark side of back-shoring emerges. Place-based policies had a bad reputation for decades, if they received any attention at all. This has recently changed, for two reasons. First, many countries have experienced political backlashes from rising spatial economic disparities. Populist movements received the highest support in economically backward regions, which had been hit by severe local shocks. By trying to foster spatial economic cohesion, regional policies have become an attempt to insure against those political trends and to save liberal democracies altogether. Second, recent theoretical and empirical research has challenged the leading paradigm of spatial equilibrium analysis, according to which place-based policies are an inefficient interference into the market-based resource allocation. In this paper, I review those arguments and how their balance has changed over time. I argue that the demand for place-based policies is likely to increase in the future, as new digital technologies might reinforce urban-rural divides. But even if the general case for place-based policies now seems to be more widely accepted, the question remains what exactly should be done and which type of programs generate the highest return. Digging through the vast evaluation literature, I try to derive some robust lessons how to conduct place-based policies in practise.
